element_texts.text:
Geo. M. Templeton.
Capt Co. "C". 32nd U.S.B.G.
From 
Canonsburg
Washington Country
Pennsylvania
Father's Address
David Templeton
Canonsburg
Penna

Pocket Diary
for
1864.
CONTAINING
A Blank Space for Every day in the Year,
CALENDAR
RATES OF POSTAGE, &C.
PUBLISHED ANNUALLY
FOR THE TRADE.
1864.

FRIDAY, JANUARY 1, 1864.
A new year comes in today
May I be able to spend it 
to better advantage than the one
now closed. Dined on hard Fork,
I hope the time may soon come
when "hard Fork will come again no more"
SATURDAY 2
I never knew such a sudden
change of weather as took place
yesterday. It grew very cold.
Could see snow on the Blue Ridge
although there was none here
it was a fine sight.
SUNDAY 3
Still very cold

THURSDAY, JANUARY 7, 1864.
Sergt. William T Easton of our
Co was appointed Sergt Major
of the 149th Regt P.V. and reported
today.
Should be 9th
FRIDAY 8
Snowed 3 or 4 inches yesterday
SATURDAY 9

MONDAY, JANUARY 4, 1864.
We have five clerks at these
headquarters now.
TUESDAY 5
Nothing new
WEDNESDAY 6
Col. Wister & Lt Funk are home
on furlough. Jim Williams
the orderly came back from
furlough.
Should be 8th

WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 13, 1864.
Ditto
THURSDAY 14
Ditto
FRIDAY 15
Had inspection in the 143rd
and 150th Regts.

SUNDAY, JANUARY 10, 1864.
Went over to Dress Parade 
at the Regt. After the parrade was
dismissed The Chaplain offered up 
a prayer. Lt Dalgliesh came back 
from Pitts bringing me books, gloves &c &c from T.A.
MONDAY 11
Commenced writing in the books
TUESDAY 12
Nothing new

TUESDAY, JANUARY 19, 1864.
Very cold. Had inspection 
in 121st Regt.
Biber came back to the Comp
the other day: he left us sick
at Frederick City Md. while
going to Penn
WEDNESDAY 20
Received my box from home
being 14 days on the road. 
Had inspection in the 142d. Regt.
THURSDAY 21
Nothing new

SATURDAY, JANUARY 16, 1864.
Had inspection in the 149th Regt.
SUNDAY 17
Nothing new
MONDAY 18
Rained all day

MONDAY, JANUARY 25, 1864.
Capt Osborne went home today
telling me to run the machine 
until he would come back.
Lt Dalgliesh is acting Inspt
Genl.
TUESDAY 26
Genl Newton wife & children
visited the Brig today. The rebs
are making a great smoke in 
their camps on the other side of the
Rapidan.  At night a great light.
WEDNESDAY 27
Went down town & took a 
stroll. We have had the finest
weather for some time.
As warm as May.

FRIDAY, JANUARY 22, 1864.
Sent in my report this morning
SATURDAY 23
Col Wister came back from
leave of absence
SUNDAY 24
Capt Glenn came back from
leave of absence. Attended 
preaching at 149th Regt. P.V.
Very good sermon on the text
"What shall I do to be saved"

SUNDAY, JANUARY 31. 1864.
Spent a very quiet Sabbath. Saw a
dozen deserters come in from the
front. A great many come in 
every day. Wm Bond of our 
Co died today in hospital at
Washington D.C.
MONDAY, FEBRUARY 1
Went down town & made Capt
Glenn promise to give me a 
recommendation next day.
Sent a note to Lt. Slagle asking
him for one.
TUESDAY 2
Received Lt Slagle's recommendation
& got one from Capt Glenn.
Made out my application and 
put it in the mail to be sent
tomorrow.

THURSDAY, JANUARY 28, 1864.
Went up on Pony Mountain arriving in time to see the sunrise. 
Had Col Dana's glass & were permitted to look
through the glasses of the Signal Corps
It was foggy but could see a battery of the Reb
Nicholls & Harry came down today
FRIDAY 29
Jones received a very large box
from some lady friend in West
Virginia. Gustin's wife came
today.
SATURDAY 30
The fine weather has ended 
and it is now raining

SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 6, 1864.
Marched soon after day light
our Div in advance, and arrived
within 2 miles of Racoon Ford
at 12'M. Stoped & made ourselves
as comfortable as possible by putting
up tents. Considerable firing on the line.
SUNDAY 7
Went down to the river or rather to
to our pickets. Could see rebs in 
the fortifications on the other side
started after dark and came on 
the double quick to camp arriving
about 8 P.M. pretty well tired out
MONDAY 8
Feel pretty tired after my
march. They told us that Gen.
Butler was advancing up the 
Peninsula & our move was made 
to keep Lee's forces on the Rapidan.

WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 3, 1864.
Captain Osborne came back this evening. 
THURSDAY 4
Nothing New
FRIDAY 5
Received marching orders at 
11 P.M. to move at 3 A M next
morning. This was very unexpected
and caused a good deal
of excitement.

FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 12, 1864.
My leave came down late at
night, & I expect to go in the 
morning.
SATURDAY 13
Started at 8 AM arriving in Wash.
at 2 P.M. Went to report but
was too late. Went to the Sanitary
Lodge, where there are 
accomodations for applicants with all the books necessary.
SUNDAY 14
Attended church at Dr Gurley's  Rev. McAuley preached from Is 54
& 2d. 1st. The design of the church. 2d. The duties of Christians
Attended 6th St Pres Church. Sermon on the parable of the false foundation

TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 9, 1864.
Received my orders to report 
at Washington for examination
Made out an application for 
(3) three days leave and sent it
up to Corps. Head Quarters.
WEDNESDAY 10
Was expecting my leave of absence
to come down but it did
not. Capt Osborne gave me 
a note to Capt Halstead. Recd order 
of the Board.
THURSDAY 11
Have heard nothing from my 
leave yet.

THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 18, 1864.
Left Washington in the 9.30 train arriving at Culpeper about 3 P.M. My success surprised some of the Officers & boys. Capt Osborne seemed especially pleased. Saw Jim Black and others as I came along.
FRIDAY 19
Had inspection in the 142d & 121st Regts. Received a letter from Prof. Caldwell. Nicholls called to see me yesterday morning, but I was not back then.
SATURDAY 20
Went up on Pony Mountain to see Nicholls who is on station there. The rebs seem to be moving to our right. I expect they are preparing to go to Pa. next summer.

MONDAY, FEBRUARY 15, 1864.
Reported at 81/2 o'clock and gave
Capt. Halstead my letter of introduction. 
Studied harder
today than I ever did before
Will be examined tomorrow. Have
no confidence. Feel as if I would
not pass.
TUESDAY 16
Was examined the second one in the 
morning; and by the assistance of
Providence kept cool & got along
very well. Ascertained I had passed
as 1st Class Captain. Heard  H. Winter Davis
make a speech on the admission of Arkansas
WEDNESDAY 17
Called on Mrs Justin & family. Heard
Senator Davis make a violent speech in
reference to the writ of habeas corpus &
attacking Massachusetts & her Senator.
Went down to the Arsenal. Called on Robertson
& Johnson  J.G & on Capt Halstead

WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 24, 1864.
Genl. Merritts 1st Division of cavalry was reviewed on the same ground that our corps was reviewed on
THURSDAY 25
Brad. Johnson came down to get information about going to Washington, before Genl. Casey's board. Went up on Pony Mt with him Mrs Gov. Curtin was there & came and had a conversation with me as I was a "Bucktail".
FRIDAY 26
Received a letter from Musser? As many as a dozen have come to me for information in reference to going to Washington

SUNDAY, FEBRUARY 21. 1864.
Nicholls came down to see me. There was a review of this Brigade today by Col. Wister preparitory to a Corps review some time during the week.
MONDAY 22
Got a horse from Capt. and went up to the 2d. Corps; saw all the boys except Geo Murray Rev Jas. Herron was there & Mr Bain had preached there the day before.
TUESDAY 23
There was a review of our Corps near our Hd Qrs. every thing passed off finely. The 2d Corps was reviewed on the plain near Stevensburg

TUESDAY, MARCH 1, 1864.
took the train This morning arriving in W. at 2.30 P.M. Too late to report. Called on Robertson & Johnson. Stoped at the Markham House. Saw John E. Black. H. Herston + Maj Scott.
WEDNESDAY 2
Called at the "Signal Camp"
Reported and learned my appointment had been sent to the 149th N. Y. received a new copy as Capt in the 32nd Regt at Camp Wm Penn. took the 7.30 P.M. train arriving in Phil. at 3 AM. stoped at the Continental 
THURSDAY 3
Bought pants, hat &c and reported at Camp Wm Penn in the afternoon & was assigned to Co. C. there are 3 Capts the 1st Lieut. & 4. 2d. Lieuts and a Surgeon. My 2d Lt is Robert W Webb. We have organised a mess of all officers in Regt.

SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 27, 1864
The 6th Corps. passed here going out towards the river, having 6 day rations
SUNDAY 28
The 1st Div. 3d. Corps passed out to the front this morning. Attended church in town, heard a first rate sermon by Rev. I W Bain from Canonsburg on Isaiah 4 & 1st verse. Was discharged by S. C. war Dept. Feb 24th 1864
MONDAY 29
Are making preparations to go to Washington in the morning and report to Maj. Foster and ascertain in reference to my appointment.

MONDAY, MARCH 7, 1864.
Have drills today. I had the Co. out, drilling them on the march by the flank &c
TUESDAY 8
W. Ward Rice reported as my 1st Lieut. I think he will make an agreeable companion and a good officer. 
WEDNESDAY 9 
I expect to start home on a 12 day furlough this week

FRIDAY, MARCH 4, 1864.
Went down town and was mustered in as Capt of Co. C. Went to see Caroline. Saw John Peck, he told me Dan Thompson, & Andy Ros & some more Canonsburgers were in Co. A. 25th the other regt in camp. saw them
SATURDAY 5
Am officer of the day of Camp William Penn. That is kind of rushing things I am thinking. Made the grand rounds and found the men pretty well posted in their duties.
SUNDAY 6
Got a pass to go to church in the city, but as Lieut W. was detailed as officer of the guard I was unable to go. We now have an asst. Surgeon & 8 2d. Lieuts & Lt. Col. 2. 1st Lieuts

SUNDAY, MARCH 13, 1864.
Attended Episcopal church between Camp & Old York Roads. Called on Major Reisynger.
MONDAY 14
Got my 12 days pass. Came to the City. went to see Caroline. Left on the 10.30 P.M. train arriving in Harrisburgh about 3 A.M.
TUESDAY 15
Took the 8 AM train for Greencastle arriving at 12 M. Took stage at 5 P.M. for Mercersburg arriving at 8 P.M. Found E.J. There having come on the same train to Chambersburg and from there to Mercersburg arriving at 5 P.M.

THURSDAY, MARCH 10, 1864.
The officers are coming in very fast now.
Col. Baird is to be our Colonel, he was a private of the Invalid Corps. 
Issued ordnance stores to Co.
FRIDAY 11
Borrowed $.20.00 from Chas Potts, to be returned at pay day. I have concluded to put off my furlough until next week.
SATURDAY 12
Major Reisynger reported for the 25th Regt.
He was Capt of Co. H 150th Pa Vols. The two regts were reviewed by Col Wagner this afternoon preparatory to a review by Genl Casey next week

SATURDAY, MARCH 19, 1864.
Went out in the coach to Canonsburg.
Found all as well as I expected, and everyone glad to see me.
SUNDAY 20
Attended church at Wm French's saw a great many of my old friends and aquaintances
MONDAY 21
Went to Prays Hall in the morning, and at noon Samuel & I started on horseback for Mary's arriving about 4 P.M

WEDNESDAY, MARCH 16, 1864.
Spent the day at Margaretta's, called to see Aunt Mary
THURSDAY 17
Started to Chambersburg at 7 A.M; and from there at 1 PM arriving at Harrisburg at 4 P.M and at Pittsburgh at 3 AM of Friday
FRIDAY 18
Spent the day in Pittsburgh

FRIDAY, MARCH 25, 1864.
Came into Pittsburgh with Father. Took the 8.35 P.M train but owing to a colision of freight trains was 3 hours behind time, arriving in Phila at 2 1/2 P.M Saturday.
SATURDAY 26
Ran around the city about 4 hours trying to have my bounty affast? straightened up but for want of a paper could not do so.
Arrived in camp at 7 P.M.
Sunday 27
Attended church in the evening.
Our

TUESDAY, MARCH 22, 1864.
Came back from Mary's stoping at Wm Templeton's and Robert Russell's
WEDNESDAY 23
Had my teeth plugged by Dr. White. Saw Sergt Wm Pollock just from the army
THURSDAY 24
Called on Dr Smith & Profs Linn & Dodd. Col. Fraser sent word that he wished to see me: had a talk with him

Thursday, March 31, 1864
Quite stormy today
Friday, April 1
Busy drilling
Saturday 2
Ditto  Are making out muster rolls

MONDAY, MARCH 28, 1864.
Was detailed as officer of the day. Was busy overseeing some improvements in camp
An order for the 32nd to report at Annapolis immediately
TUESDAY 29
Was very busy drilling
WEDNESDAY 30
Went to the city to see about my bounty papers, had my credit changed to Chartress JP and sent the certificates to Samuel to have them filed

WEDNESDAY, APRIL 6, 1864.
Wm Y Easton formerly Sergt of our Co - reported as 1st Lieut in our regt.
THURSDAY 7
Went to the city with Lieut Easton to have him mustered in & show him around the city
FRIDAY 8
Nothing new

SUNDAY, APRIL 3 1864.
Attended church at night
MONDAY 4
Lt Rice & I went to the city & had some pictures struck off. Visited "Independence Hall"
TUESDAY 5
Busy drilling

TUESDAY, APRIL 12, 1864.
The paper says the colored troops of this camp are to parade through the city tomorrow
WEDNESDAY 13
Were formed in to go to the city but it came on rain so that it was impossible to go. Rained all day.
THURSDAY 14
Went to the city marched through the principal streets. (almost 10 miles) I came back in the evening -
There were 6 cos of the 43d:5 of the 25th and our regt. Saw Todd while marching along

SATURDAY, APRIL 9, 1864.
Nothing new.
SUNDAY 10
Ditto
MONDAY 11
Ditto

MONDAY, APRIL 18, 1864.
Was Officer of the day. Had some trouble with one of the men, whom I was taking to the guard house
TUESDAY 19
Nothing new
WEDNESDAY 20
Ditto

FRIDAY, APRIL 15, 1864.
Very tired. The left wing of the 25 left this morning. We expect to leave Tuesday.
On dress parade orders were read to leave on Sunday night or Monday morning
SATURDAY 16
The orders last received were misconstrued. they are now that we are to go to the Dept of the South

as soon as convenient

SUNDAY 17
Attended church in the evening

SUNDAY, APRIL 24, 1864.
Took on board 281 deserters and convicts to be transported to the 
"Dry Tortugas". under guard of 45 of Young's Batt. under command
of Capt? Alf. Kerr. Jimmy Clark was Sergt in command got very sick. 
so with all the officers
MONDAY 25
Very sick. Staid in my berth almost all day. Passed Cape Hatteras about 9 P.M.
TUESDAY 26
Saw many sails today, and two gun boats. Quite a number of porpoises came
jumping along. They look very queer

THURSDAY, APRIL 21, 1864.
While on Battalion drill the Lt Col received a dispatch to move
immediately as the transport was waiting.
FRIDAY 22
Very busy getting ready to move in the morning
SATURDAY 23
Marched to the station and from the Phil Station to the
Vine St wharf: went on board the Steamship "Continental" and left at 3 P.M. 
Stoped at Fort Delaware at dark. & laid to all night.

SATURDAY, APRIL 30, 1864.
Moved outside the fortification and went into camp. Were mustered in by Lt Col Geary.
SUNDAY, MAY 1
Have not got our tents yet. and are trying to keep the sun off our heads by building 
little bush huts. Very warm   Making out muster rolls
MONDAY 2
Received our tents and are busy putting them up.  Finished the muster rolls

WEDNESDAY, APRIL 27, 1864.
Land in sight at daylight Landed the Col. at Port Royal at noon, and in the 
afternoon steamed up to Seabrook and landed, and marched a mile
and laid down (bivouaced)
THURSDAY 28
Laid around all day. Dont know what we are going to do.
Corn is 3 or 4 inches high.  Co. H went 4 miles to Jenkins
Island. Co B. is going to follow in the same direction
FRIDAY 29
Co I was sent down to the landing, in the morning, and in the afternoon
the remaining 7 Companies marched to Port Royal and bivouaced near the
town during the night.

FRIDAY, MAY 6, 1864.
Landed at Pawnee Landing and marched to the uper end of Folly Island. where we took ferry boat
for Morris Island. Went into camp near Fort Shaw. in sight of Sumpter & Charleston. &c
SATURDAY 7
Our baggage came up and we put up tents
SUNDAY 8
Took a walk up to Fort Wagner from which you have a fine view of Charleston and harbor.
Castle Pinkney &c.

TUESDAY, MAY 3, 1864.
Received orders to repair to Folly Island immediately.
WEDNESDAY 4
Went on board the Steamer "Cosmopolitan" about midnight and started soon after
THURSDAY 5
In sight of land at daylight. Soon came off Stono Inlet but could not cross the bar
until the afternoon. The Col landed, but could not find our destination. as the Genl was away

THURSDAY, MAY 12, 1864.
Moved camp taking up the space occupied by the left wing
FRIDAY 13
They have been firing on Sumter from the batteries and Monitors
SATURDAY 14
Firing on Sumter all day. They seem to make some impression The right wing
was inspected by Capt Pope  A.A.I.G. on Colonel Gurney's staff

MONDAY, MAY 9, 1864.
Have quite a fine camp laid out. on the Sea Shore, except the sand is 6 inches deep. The 
Ironsides & Monitors all lie about a mile out in the stream.
TUESDAY 10
The left wing went to Folly Island under command of the Major
WEDNESDAY 11
Went on picket in command of the detail of the regt. Picketed between Wagner and Gregg.

WEDNESDAY, MAY 18, 1864.
Was "Officer of the Day"
THURSDAY, 19
Received a mail. I was disappointed in not receiving anything from home recd. letters
from McEwen, Jones & Mame. Received papers  unclear Capt Hagle & some of
the boys are wounded
FRIDAY 20
Went out on picket had command in "Chatfield". Had wade in the surf
knee deep while going up.

SUNDAY, MAY 16, 1864.
Had inspection by Col Geary  Received the first mail since coming south.
MONDAY 16
Have news of the death of Gen Wadsworth. I hope Grant may succede.
TUESDAY 17
The Arago passed down so we may look for a mail soon

TUESDAY, MAY 24, 1864
I am afraid we will die of inaction in this Deptmt
WEDNESDAY 25
Nothing new
THURSDAY 26
Was field officer of the Trenches

SATURDAY, MAY 21, 1864.
Almost all our officers are geting sick, from various causes we have
only 5 or 6 for duty in the right wing.
SUNDAY 22
Nothing new
MONDAY 23
Was detailed as Field Officer of the Trenches. Have a horse
to ride which makes it quite easy.

MONDAY, MAY 30, 1864.
Nothing new
TUESDAY 31
Ditto. Was detailed on a board of survey to meet at the Post Commissary to verify discrepancy between invoiced and actual receipts of some stores.
WEDNESDAY, JUNE 1
Received a mail which was brought by the supply ship Massachusetts.

FRIDAY, MAY 27, 1864.
Received a mail, 3 letters and some papers. I see Lt. Dalgliesh is wounded, and some more of the boys of Co D.
SATURDAY 28
Nothing special
SUNDAY 29
Was Field officer of the Trenches

SUNDAY, JUNE 5, 1864.
Went on picket in evening Had preaching to the regiment by Mr Deforrest of
the Christian Commission
MONDAY 6
The board of survey was convened again.
TUESDAY 7
A transport that came down to Sumter last night stuck on the bar while
returning and our men have been very busy firing at it I understand they have injured it so as to sink her

THURSDAY, JUNE 2, 1864.
Nothing of importance crossed out
FRIDAY 3
Got Lieut Easton's horse and went down to Folly Island to see
John Easton, who had sent for me to come and see him.
Took dinner with Co.s G & K of our Regt.
SATURDAY  4
Nothing new.  Came off picket this morning

SATURDAY, JUNE 11, 1864.
Simeon Wilhelm of my company was found asleep on post. I put him
in the guard house as soon as I came into camp, & will prefer charges against him
SUNDAY 12
Read quite a number of chapters in the Testament. Received letters from Father &
Mother & Margaretta & Caldwell. I feel quite unwell. The Regt Recd orders to
go to Beaufort S.C.
MONDAY 13
Had everything in readiness to go when the order was countermanded for the
present. We are to be Brigaded there and go into a camp of instruction. Beaufort
is said to be a fine place

WEDNESDAY, JUNE 8, 1864.
Was on picket at Fort Chatfield The reb. Steamer has been completely demolished  
The left wing of the regiment came back this evening.
THURSDAY 9
Nothing new  Emanuel West of my company was put under arrest for sleeping on post
FRIDAY 10
Went on picket at Fort Wagner

FRIDAY, JUNE 17, 1864.
fired shell from all the batteries  Had a Batallion drill.
SATURDAY 18
Went on picket at Fort Gregg. Genl. Schimmelfennig came up during the night 
and I as senior officer had to do the honors. It is too bad to have such Dutchmen wearing stars.
SUNDAY 19
Had preaching in Fort Shaw Our regt. marched in and attended.

TUESDAY, JUNE 14, 1864.
Lt Withington of Co K, who has been detailed on Folly Island returned. There has
been an almost continual storm for the past 3 days
WEDNESDAY 15
Went on picket at Fort Gregg
THURSDAY 16
There was a boat race down at the wharf, between two ? boats. The rebs. opened from

one of their batteries to fire salute when our batteries opened on them. they then

THURSDAY, JUNE 23, 1864.
Levi Elletts died in Regmt'l Hospital. Lieut Cory was taken with violent convulsions this morning.
FRIDAY 24
I received letters on Monday from Major Glenn, Samuel, Nicholls & Mame.
SATURDAY 25
Was Officer of the Day & Guard  Col Baird has been in command of the post this week
in the absence of Col Gurney, who has gone to Hilton Head.  The 32nd P.V. came out from Folly

MONDAY, JUNE 20, 1864.
Lieut Easton was relieved at his own request and came back
to the company. The paymaster came and paid the officers. only one man recd the $7.00 offered
TUESDAY 21
Some more of the men were induced to take their pay. Five of my Company took it. Lloyd. Bird.
Pierce. Ray & Banks.  Col. Baird is in command of the post in the absence of Col Gurney
WEDNESDAY 22
Went on picket at Fort Wagner. Had a Batallion Drill  Guy Duncan died on the 20th and Frank
Howard on the 21st inst. both in Regmtl Hospitals

WEDNESDAY, JUNE 29, 1864.
Have a rumor that an expedition is on foot for the taking of James Island
THURSDAY 30
Have orders to be ready to move at sundown, with haversacks canteens and gum blankets
Were mustered for pay  Did not move at sundown but furnished all the pickets
FRIDAY, JULY 1
Genl Schimmelfennig crossed over to James Island and captured some prisoners & guns.
The 127th AY & 52 PV are to cross over to Fort Johnson tonight. There is no reason why
the should not succede

SUNDAY, JUNE 26, 1864.
Lieut Easton has been taken to act Adjt. owing to the sickness of Lieut Rice. Col Baird told me that Capt Pope A.A.S\I.G. had asked to be relieved and said I had better put in for the place, for certain reasons I declined
MONDAY 27
Nothing new
TUESDAY 28
Ditto

TUESDAY, JULY 5, 1864.
Genl. Schimmelfennig is very quiet and is said to be entrenching.  Hatch is said to
be on Seabrook Island
WEDNESDAY 6
Rumor has it that Capt Birney was defeated in his attack on the main land. Went on picket
at Putnam. The artillery men put a shell into a boat that was down near Johnson. No mail recd.
THURSDAY 7
Genl Schimmelfennig has opened again quite lively

SATURDAY, JULY 2, 1864.
The expedition to Ft. Johnson proved a miserable farce. Two of the boats landed,
containing some of the 52 P.V. among them the Col & Lieut & Adjt. and all were taken prisoner  
The others retreated at the first fire
SUNDAY 3
Was on picket last night at Wagner and had a fine view of the flight from Fort Johnson. The rebs
opened from Moultrie which drew the fire of Wagner, which was replied to by Moultrie
MONDAY 4
Spent quite a quiet 4th except what noise was made by our shelling the rebs on James Island

MONDAY, JULY 11, 1864.
Was on picket last night at Ft Gregg and everything was very quiet, except the firing
at a small oar boat that was going from Sumter to the city in the morning
TUESDAY 12
Nothing new
WEDNESDAY 13
Was appointed pres of a council of Administration to administer on the effects
of deceased soldiers at Post Hospital

FRIDAY, JULY 8, 1864.
Our forces evacuated James Island in the evening of this day.
SATURDAY 9
All quiet. Except that last night while I was posting the pickets in front of Fort Gregg the rebs 
opened from all their batteries with shot shell, grape & cannister, and for a time we had as much
as we could do to dodge them
SUNDAY 10
Spent a quiet Sabbath

SUNDAY, JULY 17, 1864.
Had a day of rest after coming off picket.
MONDAY 18
Took 16 men and went to Folly Island in two pontoon boats and brought two loads
went the second time and got back again 11 P.M. hauled two loads to camp by hand during the night
TUESDAY 19
Had the remainder of the lumber hauled up to camp

THURSDAY, JULY 14, 1864.
The council met.  Received a mail yesterday afternoon giving news of a rebel raid
into Maryland
FRIDAY 15
Had the regular monthly inspection by Capt Pope A.A.I.G.  Col Gurney's Staff.
SATURDAY 16
Went down to Folly Island to see if I could get some lumber to raise the tents with. Stoped to see
Lieut Webb who is on the island in charge of a wood choping party

SATURDAY, JULY 23, 1864.
The navy did not demonstrate reasons not given. The weather
is quite rough Built a mess tent for the Company
SUNDAY 24
Had a quiet day
MONDAY 25
It has been cold stormy weather, accompanied with rain for some days. 
Not much like the ideal South Carolina July.

WEDNESDAY, JULY 20, 1864.
Started at raising the tents, and had a splendid floor put in mine
THURSDAY 21
Finished most of the tents
FRIDAY 22
Finished all the men's tents. Went on picket. The rain poured down all night.
The navy were expected to make a demonstration against Sumter. Col Gurney & others camp
Putnam up to Fort

FRIDAY, JULY 29, 1864.
Nothing new
SATURDAY 30
Received a mail. Lieuts Berryman and Pierce received
30 days leave of absence and started for N. York.
SUNDAY 31
Went on picket as Field Officer of the Trenches. Lieut Crawford
received his discharge and started for home

TUESDAY, JULY 26, 1864.
The seige of Sumter is kept up with vigor. Was on picket as Field Officer
of the Trenches
WEDNESDAY 27
They are engaged in building a new fortification connecting Forts Chatfield
and Putnam on which they are going to mount heavy guns for the reduction of Fort Sumter
THURSDAY 28
Was officer of the Day

THURSDAY, AUGUST 4, 1864.
The flag of Truce boat came down the harbor having the officers held in Charleston, on board. 
The Cosmopolitan went to meet it having their prisoners on board. An exchange was effected
and our officers started for N.Y.
FRIDAY 5
Although Col. Dana was exchanged and passed within a short distance of us, we were unable to see
him as the boat did not touch at the dock. I would have liked so much to have met him. Mrs. Merrills arrived.
SATURDAY 6
The paymaster came and paid the officers. Did not have money to pay the men, although he has received
orders to pay $16 per month. Went on picket at Payne's Dock. Another torpedo expedition to Fort Sumter
fizzled this night

MONDAY, AUGUST 1, 1864.
Nothing new
TUESDAY 2
The jails for the reb prisoners have been completed but there is talk that 
they will not be occupied, as they have agreed to exchange our officers for them.
WEDNESDAY 3
Three officers of the 3rd Ohio Reg made their escape from Charleston and
came in to our pickets at Fort Putnam, having been prisoners 15 months. They
were being sent from Macon to Charleston. and made their escape and got
a boat & rowed down the harbor

WENESDAY, AUGUST 10, 1864.
Went on picket at Fort Wagner.
THURSDAY 11
As it rained yesterday it interfered with the court martial and it was postponed until today.
Five of my men came from Camp Wm Penn.
FRIDAY 12
Lieut Geise brought 43 of the regt who had been left at Camp Wm Penn

SUNDAY, AUGUST 7, 1864.
A medical board has decided that Colonel Baird should go home on account
of his health. We are looking for a mail. I have not had a letter for nearly a month
MONDAY 8
Nothing new
TUESDAY 9
Am summoned to attend the trial of Simeon Wilhelm as a witness tomorrow

TUESDAY, AUGUST 16, 1864.
Received orders to pack up and report to Genl Foster at Port Royal for orders; the
impression is that we are going north, to Grant.
WEDNESDAY 17
Marched at daylight. Crossed Lighthouse Inlet in pontoon boats and marched
to Pawnee and there went aboard the Delaware leaving about 5 PM. and arrived
at Port Royal about midnight
THURSDAY 18
Landed about 10 A.M. and bivouaced about 1/2 of a mile from town. The impression
is that we are not going out of the Department.

SATURDAY, AUGUST 13, 1864.
Went on picket
SUNDAY 14
A very quiet day
MONDAY 15
Was officer of the day

MONDAY, AUGUST 22, 1864.
Have been in the service two years today
TUESDAY 23
Received letters from Caldwell and Musser
WEDNESDAY 24
There is a detail of 400 men out of our regt each day to work on the fort

FRIDAY, AUGUST 19, 1864.
Moved outside the intrenchment about 1/2 a mile and went into camp.
Our business is to build a new fort.
SATURDAY 20
Laid out the camp and stuck up tents.
SUNDAY 21
Worked all day policing camp as we expect a detail to work on the
fort tomorrow

SUNDAY, AUGUST 28, 1864.
Marched as soon as Lt Easton and those in town were relieved which was about 10 A.M. 
Arrived at Spanish Wells about 2 P.M. after a very warm dusty march of 7 miles. Reported to
Capt Mesnard Co B. 25th Ohio V.V. Infantry
MONDAY 29
The Capt gave us today to put up quarters. Put up an arbor in front of the row. of men's tents.
extending the full length of the street. Was almost eaten up by musquitoes.
TUESDAY 30
But all "present for duty" at work on the fort which is to be a 4 gun battery, commanding the
mouth of May River. This is a pretty nice place to camp, but is very lonesome

THURSDAY, AUGUST 25, 1864.
The men were paid off up to June 30th 1864, at the rate of $13 to the 1st of May at $16 since. 
About $50,000 was paid to the regiment. A great deal was expressed home.
FRIDAY 26
A detail was made from the regt. for town guard not one for Provost guard.
on the Dock.
SATURDAY 27
Received an order in the evening to take my company to Spanish Wells to work on the fortifications

SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 3, 1864.
The rebs opened battery of six guns on Tuesday from Chimney Point on a ferry boat
that was coming up the creek. Struck her once. Next day two schooners and two tugs
came up and shelled the woods. no reply.
SUNDAY 4
Had the most quiet Sabbath since the regt. came out. Not a man on duty. The duty of the
officers now consists in attending three roll calls per day. Lt. Webb did come away from the Regiment.
MONDAY 5
Nothing new

WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 31, 1864.
Genl Potter came up in the afternoon of yesterday and the men were
called in off the work expecting to be inspected, but were not: the other Co. was.
Was mustered by Capt Randall 25th Ohio V.V. Infantry.
THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 1
Col. Geary and 2M. McGinley came up yesterday evening expecting to muster us, 
but it had already been done. They staid for supper. The picket near our tent saw some men trying
to get to the sound and fired on them
FRIDAY 2
I now place two men out at night to guard against surprise. It is quite tedious to spend a
day doing nothing. The boys are making good progress at the fort

FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 9, 1864.
Lieut Easton went to town and got the mail. National Salutes were fired by the Army
& Navy at the head and I saw Fort Pulaski fire one although we could not hear the guns.
SATURDAY 10
All day reading up the newspapers
SUNDAY 11
Nothing new

TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 6, 1864.
We hear from rebel sources that Fort Morgan in Mobile Bay has surrendered.
WEDNESDAY 7
Went to town to get the mail & a number of articles for the men, but the mail
Steamer had not arrived. By another boat the news of the nomination of
McClellan & Pendleton for Pres. & V. Pres.
THURSDAY 8 
Nothing new

THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 15, 1864.
Nothing new.
FRIDAY 16
The mail boat came in. Lieut Berryman & Capt Pratt came in it.
SATURDAY 17
Lieut Berryman and a Mr Wilson called to see us. Received our mail
in the evening

MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 12, 1864.
Went fishing and succeeded in catching some fine fish and also
succeeded in catching a large hook into my finger, which had to be cut out
TUESDAY 13
Went fishing in a boat and caught quite a number of fish.
WEDNESDAY 14
Went to Town, and stoped at the Regiment.  Expected to get the mail but
the boat had not arrived  Lieut Webb went on the Steamer yesterday on a 30 days leave

WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 21, 1864.
Quite heavy firing in the direction of Savannah.
THURSDAY 22
Had the regular monthly inspection on a ten minutes notice.
The mail boat has arrived bringing Col. Baird
FRIDAY 23
Lieut Easton and I went on board the "Plato" and  went to "Fort Pulaski".
This is a large work mounting 64 guns. is on Cockspur Island at the mouth of
Savannah river, distant from Savannah 12 miles, the spires of which I saw.
The fort has been repaired since the bombardment when Capt Gilmore demolished one angle
entirely

SUNDAY, SEPTEMBER 18, 1864.
Very quiet
MONDAY 19
Went to the "Memphis" which is blockading the mouth of the sound. Was cordially 
received by? the officers. She is a Clyde built Steamer, captured from rebs &
mounts 13 guns.
TUESDAY 20
Had some rain

SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 24, 1864.
Got back from Fort Pulaski about 8 unclear The Plato was taking some of the 25th Oh to
relieve some of the 3rd R.I H Art. whose time was out. Went to town. Saw Col B & Capt Pratt,
found Lt Pollock been made a 1st Lt. insted of Nelson hon dis
SUNDAY 25
The men have nothing to do but prepare for and attend inspection
MONDAY 26
Nothing new

MONDAY, OCTOBER 3, 1864.
Busy making out returns  Lieut Ferguson caught a shark weighing some 150 lbs 7ft 2 in long. 
Having a mouth 8 in in width and capable opening it 10 inches
TUESDAY 4
Went to town. Col. Baird, Maj Thompson and some other officers went on board the "Mayflower" intending
to go to Fort Pulaski but the boat got aground opposite Chimney Point & they had to go back to camp
WEDNESDAY 5
The party for Pulaski succeeded in accomplishing their intended journey.

FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 30, 1864.
Lieut E. went to town and brought papers confirming the good news.
SATURDAY, OCTOBER 1
Went fishing with Lt Ferguson Co. B. 25 Ohio caught a great many fish. Towards
evening a large shark took off a good many of our hooks. While breaking one he
jumped out of the water, was 5 or 6 feet 
SUNDAY 2
When I came into the service I commenced reading the New Testament since that I have 
read a chapter now and a chapter then, as I had time & today I finished. Read the shorter
Catechism through

SUNDAY, OCTOBER 9, 1864.
Went to see Maj smith in reference to paying the Co.  Found that he had started for this place. 
Came back and found him ready to pay the Co. Was paid to Aug 31st. Dr Wight came up and examined some men for discharge
MONDAY 10
The corporal of engineers did not have the men to work in the afternoon as they told him
they had nothing to eat. They had everything but meat. They rather played off on him. I tied up one
man for starting the fuss
TUESDAY 11
Went down to the regt. found there had been a new 2nd Lt assigned to the Regt.
We look for Lt Webb on the next Steamer.

THURSDAY, OCTOBER 6, 1864.
Nothing new
FRIDAY 7
The rumor is that the prisoners are going to be exchanged near Fort Pulaski.
SATURDAY 8
Nothing new

SATURDAY, OCTOBER 15, 1864.
Went with Capt Mesnard and ten of his men up May River as far as the dock.
Made a raft of some of the plank and towed it to camp. Found a torpedo which had washed ashore 
above the dock.
SUNDAY 16
Spent a very quiet Sabbath. The mens guns and accoutrements looked very well. Rodgers
having a fashion of going away at night found it necessary to retain him by "force of rope."
MONDAY 17
The mail steamer came in from the north. But Lieut Webb did not come. 2nd Lieut Glidden reported
and was assigned to Co. A. A new Hospital Steward reported for duty

WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 12, 1864.
The boys that went to town brought news that the regt was packing up expecting to go to Beaufort
THURSDAY 13
Lt. Easton went to town and found that Cos I.H.E.D. & G ready to go to Beaufort to build
a fort there to mount 24 guns. He was detailed to go with that detachment as Adjt & Q.M.
FRIDAY 14
Lieut Easton left for Beaufort  Lt. Webb absent without leave. I find it quite dull without
Lieut Easton

FRIDAY, OCTOBER 21, 1864.
Look a ride with Capt. Mesnard along the Picket line. I think the finest of view of woods is on this line, where the large trees are literally clothed with grey moss, which hangs drooping down.
SATURDAY 22
There was an alarm last night. Some boats came over to the upper post and were fired on by the pickets when they retreated. My co was under arms in 2 minutes.
SUNDAY 23
A very quiet sabbath.

TUESDAY, OCTOBER 18, 1864.
Have not yet received the mail.  Received news that we would be inspected tomorrow
WEDNESDAY 19
Was inspected by Capt Jewett of Genl Porter's Staff.  He said my Co. looked the best of any Co. he had seen.  Received letters from home  & Jim Black.
THURSDAY 20
Went to town.  Was introduced to Lt Glidden.  Bought Heavy Art Tactics. $2.00.  The orders are that our Regt is to relieve the 25th Ohio from picket duty and they are to go to town

THURSDAY, OCTOBER 27, 1864.
Went yesterday over to the old dock and built a large raft of plank from the dock and towed it to camp.  Saw a deer on Savage Island, but did not get a shot at.  Lt Custer came today instead of yesterday
FRIDAY 28
Went to Braddock's point with Lt Custer.  Dr Mason came up yesterday and excused 2 sick of my company. Peter Davis, O Holmes. W Johnson. H McLane, I Lemnes? & W Strother joined as recruits from depot
SATURDAY 29
Made out the Muster rolls.  Francis A Howard & Joseph Armstrong joined from sick in Summit House Hospital

MONDAY, OCTOBER 24, 1864.
Co. B. 25th left for town and Co. H unclear came in and took their place. I put my Co on guard: as Capt Smiths men were tired marching
TUESDAY 25
Went to Seabrook saw Capt Woodward on Jenkins Island. Read a mail. A letter from Mrs. Fars saying she heard her husband had been wounded in a battle & wished to hear from him.
WEDNESDAY 26
Lieut. Easton came up with me last night. Co. K. came up late in the evening. My co is to finish the fort and afterwards to occupy it. Lt Custer came this far on his way to his Co at Braddocks Point

WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 2, 1864.
Lieut. Webb came back from absent without leave. Lieut Thomas reported for duty and was assigned to Co. "D".
THURSDAY 3
Lieut. Webb went on picket and as it rained all night it was quite unpleasant.
FRIDAY 4
Lt Webb went to Regimental Hd Qrs and was detailed in charge of a party of wood cutters. Dr Mason came to live with us.

SUNDAY, OCTOBER 30, 1864.
Had Inspection at 10½ A.M. I received a box containing a number of books from home the other day
MONDAY 31
There was one or two boats came over to the lower post where it was fired on which awakened the camp & quite a number fired at it.  Retreated up May River.  Was mustered by the Col for the months of Sept & Oct.
TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 1
Went to town with Lt Custer. Got my pass renewed.  Called on Lt. Suitor to have details for work made from other Cos. as well as C  He was willing and referred me to Col Brown Comdg DIstrict.  Called on his Adjt Genl.

TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 8, 1864.
Moved the Co tents to the other end of the square. I hope the country may this day be saved & that the people may give their voice for human freedom
WEDNESDAY 9
Lieut & I with 8 or 10 men went over on Bull Island to where Col Seabrook lived & appropriated some of the property left by him. The rose bushes in the yard were in full bloom.
THURSDAY 10
Commenced building our house which is to be 16 by 17 feet. Steamer from the north arrived but no election news of course.

SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 5, 1864.
Lt Easton & I went up May River and tore down the most of the dock that was remaining and brought it over.
SUNDAY 6
Inspected the three companies and took about 60 of the worst looking men & inspected them in the afternoon. Head that Dr Green has been honorably discharged
MONDAY 7
Went to Seabrook. Saw Lieut Thomas on my way down. Drew my stationary for last month. Lieut Eaton came back with me.

MONDAY, NOVEMBER 14, 1864.
Went up May River and got two boat loads of bricks. Relieved a detail on a council of administration.
TUESDAY 15
Worked on the house all day Burnt some lime of oyster shells.
WEDNESDAY 16
Had General Inspection by Capt E.S. Jewett which was a very superficial affair. Col Baird came with the inspector.

FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 11, 1864.
Col Baird paid a visit to the line: came up last night and this morning. I sent him to Broad Point: he returned & rode along our line, came near being hurt by his horse sinking in quick sand.
SATURDAY 12
Received a mail, but nothing for your humble servant. Had the men out policing the camp.
SUNDAY 13
Col Baird inspected the troops and expressed himself pleased with the improvement that has been made since the last time he saw them. A boat brings news that Lincoln carried all but Mo. Ky & N.J.

SUNDAY, NOVEMBER 20, 1864.
Was to be inspected by the Col but it rained so that he did not appear.
MONDAY 21
Received an invitation from the field & staff to be present for dinner on Thanksgiving. I intend geting up an oyster dinner for the men of the command.
TUESDAY 22
The weather was so rough that I could not go for oysters

THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 17, 1864.
Lt Webb returned 
Went to Seabrook thinking the Council might meet. Capt Crissey was sick & Captain Woodward in town as witness on a Court Martial so did not meet.
FRIDAY 18
The Council met at Seabrook and recommended a Mr Hall as Sutler for the Regt. Taxed the acting Sutler $50 per month & appropriated $20 per Co. for a thanksgiving dinner
SATURDAY 19
Went over to Bull Island and procured a lot of lumber Lt Easton went to Tybee Isl. in charge of a detachment to do garrison duty there. He went yesterday.

SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 26, 1864.
Was about ready to march when I received an order not to start until early tomorrow morning. Drilled the men on the loadings and firings
SUNDAY 27
Marched at 4 1/2 AM arriving t Seabrook at 1AM the first detachment to arrive. Went into bivouac with orders to be ready to move at any time.
MONDAY 28
Had a good nights sleep in the Adjutants office. Received a letter from home. Capts Plummier & Farnsworth were relieved from duty on Court Martial and came intend to come along

WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 23, 1864.
Went over to Bull Island and got 10 or 12 gallons of oysters. Put the orderly of Co H to baking pies. Baked 65. Have 35 lbs butter 1 1/2 barrels of soda crackers: 3 1/2 bushels sweet potatoes.
THURSDAY 24
The men's dinner passed off very well indeed. every man had as much as he could eat. Went to Seabrook to dinner. Six school marms. Col Pierce Q.M.D. Lt Col Leares? Capts Manning & Jewett & the Capts of the Reg were present
FRIDAY 25
After I had retired for the night I received orders to have my command at Seabrook tomorrow afternoon. Gave the cooks orders to have 5 day meat cooked again daybreak

FRIDAY, DECEMBER 2, 1864.
Lt. Winter Co A was wounded through the thigh, and is in this hospital Lieut Guthrie formerly orderly of Co B 25th Ohio is also here with thigh broken.
SATURDAY 3
My wound does not pain me much
SUNDAY 4
Read a sermon

TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 29, 1864.
The "Neptune" came for us about 11 1/2 PM & we left for Hilton Head arriving there in time to see the transports pass us. Col B went ashore but Genl Potter had gone, went to Genl. Foster who gave orders to follow the navy: did so: got aground but were the first Regt of the Brig to land about 830 AM. Marched 3 miles and established a picket line about 8 P.M. the other unclear 
WEDNESDAY 30
came up: when we found we were on the wrong road. Got on the right road and bivouaced at 10 PM near a church. Advanced about 1 AM soon for the enemy's artillery. While our Regt. was advancing on the double quick, the orderly was shot down the first shot, Corp Davis the 2nd. Lt Col Geary was wounded. Col Baird ordered me to act field off. after driving the rebs we found them again. 32nd formed on extreme right, went in on our own unclear as no staff off. came near us, lost a good many, was wounded in knee about 4 P.M.
THURSDAY, DECEMBER 1
Had my wound dressed and rode Dr Wights horse as far as the dock arriving about 8 P.M. of the 30th went on board a Hosp Steamer and arrived at HH. but off had to go to Beaufort arrived 5 AM and got a good bed in officers Hospital

THURSDAY, DECEMBER 8, 1864.
Capts. Woodward & Farnsworth & Lt Thomas came in wounded. Also 8? or 10 others, among whom Col Gurney they were wounded yesterday morning
FRIDAY 9
Made out an application for leave of absence. Capt Woodward died about 11 last night, and was buried sometime today. He was one of the best officers of the Regt. and every one knew him only to love him. His death will be a great loss.
SATURDAY 10
Some more officers came among whom Col Siliman of 26th U.S.V.S? leg amputated. Col Geary came on a visit: he is geting better, but will not be well for some time. He brought my valise.

MONDAY, DECEMBER 5, 1864.
Had a very quiet day, my wound did not pain me at all.
TUESDAY 6
About midnight my wound began to pain me and continued all day.  I had a very high fever which was the cause of it.  Was very sick in thre evening.
WEDNESDAY 7
Col Hartwell, Lt Poreck and two other officers received note to be ready to go north on this steamer.  But don't get off until early next morning

WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 14, 1864.
Went out to see my boys who are in Hosp. Found Lohman, Ringgold, Saddler, Beatty, Black Mitchell, Thompson Wilson Warfle could not find Rodgers
THURSDAY 15
My leg does not feel so well to-day. I think I walked too much yesterday. Major Randall died last night and was buried today.
FRIDAY 16
Went on the Genl Hooker to the "Head", but found the Fulton would not sail today, being detained for dispatches from Genl Sherman. Got a state room.

SUNDAY, DECEMBER 11, 1864.
Spent a quiet Sabbath, but did not read as much sa I should. The battle of the 30th is known as Honey Hill.
MONDAY 12
My wound does not pain me much. Major Randall 25th Ohio had his leg amputated above the knee. Hear Shermans guns at Savannah
TUESDAY 13
Corporal Jacob A Davis died from the effects of his wound, in Hosp at this place. I see by paper that Corpl Gilbert was killed at Honey Hill

TUESDAY, DECEMBER 20, 1864.
Ran into Fortress Monroe and put Col. B. & Col. M. & mails ashore.
WEDNESDAY 21
Arrived in N.Y. about day light: could not get up to the wharf. About 10 AM went ashore in a small boat. Got one month's pay. Stoped at the International
THURSDAY 22
Saw Wilson class of '47 and Herron the inventor. Started in 7 P.M train last night from peir No 2. Arrived in Pitt. 2 P.M. Surprised them. Dont think of going home until Saturday

SATURDAY, DECEMBER 17, 1864.
Waiting for the dispatches. Left the wharf about 9 P.M. and went about a mile but anchored on account of the fog, which was dense. Saw 14 officers who escaped from the rebs.
SUNDAY 18
Hove anchor about 8 ½ AM and got well on our way, although the fog was very thick. Col Geary is in the state room with me. Have a Lt Col of Grants Staff on board, the bearer of dispatches.
MONDAY 19
Made Hatteras light in the evening. The Lt Col of Grants staff is Babcock: Colonel Markland Sherman's mail agent is aboard also.

FRIDAY, DECEMBER 23, 1864.
Went over to Allegheny and saw Caldwell & Henry Stewart & some others. Stewart tells me that Billy Templeton, White, Lieth? & Potts are dead, died prisoners. Am unable to get to C in the morning as all the tracks are fill
SATURDAY 24
Started from Pitt at 6.30 AM arrived in Wheeling Va. 12 M.
SUNDAY 25
